About This Game

In 1986, the world's worst nuclear disaster occurred at the Chernobyl power station. Soviet authorities established a 30km 'Exclusion Zone' around this nuclear wasteland, but in 2006 a second explosion rocked the stricken reactor, obliterating all living things and causing the Zone's boundaries to ripple outwards. From this epicenter came waves of mutated creatures, deadly radiation, and a strange, anomalous energy. The Zone was cordoned off by the military, who would shoot on sight anyone foolish enough to brave the horrors within.

It is now 2012 - man has ventured further and further into the heart of the Zone driven by reports of strange 'artifacts' imbued with anomalous energy. Mercenaries and bounty hunters compete to recover these artifacts, which command extortionate prices on the black market. Others seek to find the truth behind the Zone, while some merely revel in the desolate lawlessness of the place. Whatever their motivation, over time these individuals - Scavengers, Trespassers, Adventurers, Loners, Killer, Explorers and Robbers - have become known as S.T.A.L.K.E.R.s.

Awakening in the Zone, you are one such S.T.A.L.K.E.R., fighting for survival in this man-made Hell, while trying to discover the truth behind Chernobyl's sinister past and ominous future.

  • An immersive storyline seamlessly blended with a living, breathing, non-linear open-world environment governed by the revolutionary 'A-Life' system.
  • Accurately modeled real-world buildings and locations from deep inside the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone.
  • Unique 'Survival FPS' game play - combines action, stealth, survival and RPG elements to create an incomparable experience in the Zone.
  • Enemy Threat Evaluation AI system - NPC characters react dynamically to environments and situations.
  • Brutally realistic combat mechanics - weapons display accurate ballistic properties and can be modified with silencers and telescopic scopes.
  • Dynamic day/night and weather system directly impacts game play.
  • Advanced physics and dynamic lighting effects powered by the proprietary 'X-Ray Engine'.
  • Intense multiplayer action, supporting up to 32 players.
READ MORE

System Requirements

    Minimum: Microsoft® Windows® XP (Service Pack 2)/Microsoft® Windows® 2000 SP4, Intel Pentium 4 2 Ghz/AMD XP 2200+, 512 MB RAM, 10 GB available hard drive space, 128 MB DirectX® 9c compatible card/ nVIDIA® GeForce™ 5700/ATI Radeon® 9600, DirectX® 9 compatible sound card, LAN/ Internet connection with Cable/DSL speeds for multiplayer, Keyboard, Mouse

    Recommended: Intel Core 2 Duo E6400/AMD Athlon 64 X2 4200+, 1 GB RAM or better, 256 MB DirectX® 9c compatible card/ nVIDIA® GeForce™ 7900/ ATI Radeon® X1850

1 person found this review funny
Section-Nine
247 products in account
2 reviews
Recommended
593.4 hrs on record
Posted: September 17
Many moons ago in 2003 I stumbled upon a trailer for a game called S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Oblivion Lost
YouTube™ Video: S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Oblivion Lost trailer 2003 
Views: 72,838
"Oblivion Lost" trailer 2003 Music : Dmitry "Kaos" Kuzmenko - Invisible Dangers Part﻿ II
Needless to say after watching that I quickly became obsessed with this game. Searching high and low for every bit of info I could get my eyes on, The GSC forums became my 2nd home while I awaited its arrival.

I remember at the time I was playing Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind, With it I fell in love with non-linear open world 1st/3rd person games with RPG elements and how much I could get immersed in virtual worlds. I am all for fantasy settings don't get me wrong, but there is nothing more terrifying than reality. (With a spin of fiction of course, alternate reality if you will) The abandoned urban/industrial locations in S.T.A.L.K.E.R. were more my cup of tea. That in itself made me very excited to play it. I couldn't wait to get lost in its world.

While I waited though I researched about the Nuclear disaster at Chernobyl in April 1986, it was mixed emotions for me. I was sad/amazed/intrigued. Sad for all of those people who lost their lives because of this. Nothing but respect for the liquidators and anyone involved in the initial cleanup. Those people are heroes and deserve nothing less. Amazed that this game had some real history in its background story. Even if it is incredibly embellished (mutants, anomalies, artifacts etc etc.), you have to admit it makes for an interesting premise to a story. Finally, Intrigued on what these game developers had in store for the players to experience, without making a mockery of those who had lost their lives in this tragedy. The game also borrows elements from "Roadside Picnic" by Boris and Arkady Strugatsky and the 1979 Andrei Tarkovsky film "Stalker". If you haven't heard or checked them out yet, they are most definitely worth it. Masterpieces in their own right.

Well turns out it was a long wait lol, game finally arrived in March 2007. It was no longer Oblivion Lost, it was now called Shadow of Chernobyl. Which was a welcomed change imo, what was not a welcomed change was the amount of content/features that were removed from the game. Vehicles, locations/maps made smaller and simpler, monsters/mutants, superior lighting from old alpha builds among many other things had been removed it was rather disappointing to say the least. The survival aspect of the game took a huge hit, leaving many in the community confused as to what happened during development. GSC Game World regardless of all the missing features still delivered a good game and it was well received by critics as well.

The game at release had performance issues and bugs that required some patching. Once that happened it was clear that S.T.A.L.K.E.R. - Shadow of Chernobyl was a game ahead of its time. In a league all its own and a true gem in the PC gaming world. The atmosphere takes front row seat in this game it is almost like another character in the game. Such believable atmosphere it is downright amazing, it keeps you on the edge of your chair as you play.

Pros :
- Incredible atmosphere!
- Impressive use of lighting and shadows,
- Cloud shadows that shift as day/night cycles progress.
- None stylized (photo based) textures (adds to the realism), Replicating the rust and decay feel.
- Great cut-scenes that hold up even by today's standards.
- Plenty of side quests
- Exploring is encouraged to find secret stashes scattered throughout the world to find loot, weapons, ammo, suits and artifacts. Artifacts can be placed on your belt to grant the player abilities like resistance to radiation, increase weight limit etc. Some interesting combinations that can be made with the multitude of artifacts available in the game.
- The games AI can be quite challenging because they adapt/react/flank/take cover depending on your approach. This adds to the games replayability immensely, if its one thing I have learned playing this game is that when it comes to killing the AI is that no playthrough is ever the same. Never. They are very unpredictable lets put it that way.
- Trading system with merchants and other friendly AI characters
- "The Zone" is alive even when you are not in the same vicinity, AI will be fighting mutants and/or other factions (Bandits, Duty, Freedom, Loners, Military, Mercs, Ecologists & Monolith) All fight among themselves.

Besides all the bells and whistles the story is incredibly engaging and keeps you interested throughout. Without too many spoilers (I am sure most people reading this have already played this but still) You play as "Marked One" an amnesiac trying to retrace his steps, he is then set on a mission to the heart of "The Zone" (term used to refer to the 30 kilometer Chernobyl Exclusion Zone, established after the accident.) to find a target and their whereabouts. Game also has multiple endings depending on the choices made by the player, 7 in total.

Cons :
- Lots of "fetch" side quests (Surprise? lol)
- AI that can sometimes see you from "miles" away (vanilla)
- Some quest giving characters can die. (vanilla)

Just a heads up. Nothing game breaking but worth noting. Just like all games, it is not perfect. :)

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The mod scene for S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games is very much alive.

When your done with vanilla (though not necessary, I would recommend the community fixes of ZRP goes well in a first playthrough to have the best bug-free experience with the game). Shadow of Chernobyl has some amazing mods worth playing, especially if you are looking for new storyline or another playthrough with better visuals, more weapons, new side quests, improved enemy AI, realistic weapon damage & accuracy etc. Some I can recommend are:

- ZRP (Zone Reclamation Project) (community fixes keeps vanilla intact) ZRP
- Priboi Story
- L.U.R.K.
- OGSE (Old Good Stalker Evolution)
- AMK v1.4
- Secret Trails 2
- ABC Inferno (if you are a masochist)
- Narodnaya Solyanka variants (my favorite Narodnaya Soljanka DMX 1.3.2 dkz02)
- Autumn Aurora
- STALKER Soup
- Oblivion Lost
- AMK: Autumn Edition
- Lost Alpha (standalone)

Some of these mods add in the cut content (mutants, weapons, vehicles etc.)

The list goes on really, just my humble recommendations on the ones I have tried.

Clear Sky and Call of Pripyat are awesome games as well, worth checking out at least once. They also have great mods which I will not mention in this review. But I will say that there is something about Shadow of Chernobyl's allure and atmosphere that didn't carry over as well to the other two games. Out of all three games, Shadow of Chernobyl is by far still my favorite.

I don't claim to know everything about these games, because honestly I don't. I still discover new things about them every time I play them. They are gifts that just keep on giving. Thank goodness for Eastern European game developers!

5 stars ( ★ ★ ★ ★ ★ ) out of 5

Chernobyl is the most hostile environment on earth to human life. Radiated monsters, military shooting everything, random russian dudes walking around with other worldly artifacts making them superhuman.

Telep0rting Awes0me Guy
191 products in account
17 reviews
Recommended
51.8 hrs on record
Posted: September 13
Gameplay
+ Good simple HUD.
+ A shop trading system.
+ Inventory system and looting.
+ Controls are fully alright and work fine.
+ Different types of mutants a great addition.
+ Scary at times, keeps the direction perfect.
+ Requires skills and tactics as well taking cover.
+ Weapons are solid and actually similar to real guns.
+ No level system bs. It makes the immersion more real.
+ Mod support. Many mods to make it even more greater.
+ One of the most atmospheric games, it feels like you are there.
+ Guns have conditions the more worse quality the more the jamming.
+ Artifacts can be used to enchance some statistics or sold for money.
+ Ahh just lay down in the campfire eat sausages and listen to guitar with fellow stalkers

- Few side quests.
- Multiplayer is dead.
- Not true open-world.
- Loading times can get long.
- No weapon or armor upgrading.
- Some guns really can use many improvements.
- No engaging tutorial, only text pretty barebone's.
- No fast traveling, requiring you to walk back many times.
- Bugs and many many of them luckily there are mods that fix emm.
- Many artifacts are just scrambled around and require no real work to get.


Graphics
+ Overall graphics are pretty fine and good.
+ Lighting effects are amazing just a well done job

- Textures can use many improvements.

A.i
（Artificial intelligence )
+ Every mutant behaves in different ways thus adding variation.
+ Just amazing, they take cover,they try to flank you and have a mind.
+ The world A.i is always on i mean suppose you are in other area if you go back to other ones different things can happen like for say a loner camp and now a group of bloodsuckers attacked it.

- Buggy,buggy A.i while what it does is amazing but many times just buggs buggs ethier they will get stucked at a certain position, not respond or come and many more.

Story
+ Immersion and real immersion.
+ A unique while a bit super natural story.
+ Great voice acting matches every character.
+ A believable world and based on an actual location.
+ Many turning points and just keeps wanting you to play.

- While can be alot confusing for starters.

Design
+ Overall environment really just great.
+ Well designed world and actually does seem believable.
+ Overall presentation is great already gives you a feeling of pure bitterness.

- Many generic and poor design decisions.

Sounds and OST
+ Environmental sounds are just amazing.
+ Guns,walking and all that have great sounds
+ Great guitar-tracks keeps you listening even more.
+ Menu music and all in between may seem odd but fully matching.

- Dynamic music option. It's really not that great mostly just really lame.

Conclusion
A hella great game but more of a experience. Well directed,good voice acting,solid guns,many realistic elements, tactical, good A.i,Different mutants while some poor design decisions and many bugs and missing features.

But if you can handle its issues a definitely worth getting game and something not so easily forgettable
